THERE ARE several similarities between US policy in 1979 toward Iran and its policy in 2011 toward Egypt. First, the President Barack Hussein Obama II administration appears to be pursuing a policy of leaving all options open. Like James Earl "Jimmy" Carter, Jr.

President Barack Hussein Obama II 's tone toward Muhammad Hosni Mubarak sounded surprisingly harsh, and even insulting. President Barack Hussein Obama II disclosed in a press conference on January 28 that after hearing Muhammad Hosni Mubarak 's speech to the Egyptian people, he told him over the phone that he had a responsibility to give meaning to those words. President Barack Hussein Obama II insisted that the Egyptian leadership`` take concrete steps'' and not limit itself to rhetorical promises.

But it was White House press secretary Robert Lane Gibbs who went beyond President Barack Hussein Obama II by issuing what sounded like an implicit

to Egypt. At a press briefing, he stated that the Egyptian government had to address the`` legitimate grievances'' of the people`` immediately.''

A journalist then popped the question to Robert Lane Gibbs : You say that these legitimate grievances have to be addressed. I'm wondering.

Or what? Robert Lane Gibbs came back:`` We will be reviewing our assistance posture based on events that take place in the coming days.''
